content:
Defenders in rugby league coordinate their tackles and manipulate the ball carrier to force turnovers in a number of ways:

1. Line speed: Defenders try to limit the time and space the ball carrier has with the ball. They do this by sprinting up in a straight line, working together as a defensive line to shut down the space in front of the ball carrier. This forces the ball carrier to make decisions quickly under pressure.

2. Communication: Defenders communicate with each other to make sure they are all on the same page. They shout out calls and directions to let their teammates know where they need to be and who they need to mark.

3. Tackle technique: Defenders focus on getting their positioning and technique right for a tackle. They aim to hit the ball carrier low and wrap their arms around the legs to bring them down to the ground.

4. Ball strips: Defenders also look to manipulate the ball carrier by stripping the ball from their grasp. This is done by one defender holding up the attacker, while another defender comes in from the side to rip the ball away.

5. Interceptions: Defenders also look for opportunities to intercept passes. This requires reading the game and anticipating where the ball is going to be thrown next.

By working together as a unit and focusing on these areas, defenders can coordinate their tackles and manipulate the ball carrier to force turnovers, giving their team a chance to attack.
